comments.body: Looks like we're resolving this class type reference incorrectly

This is because `module.exports.K = K` doesn't create an alias like `export { K }` does. Filed #40155 to track this, where the real fix is probably to make at least the previous construction create an export alias.

comments.body: I'm not sure why this worked before, but the code tries to assign `Omit<X, "p">` to `X` and that *definitely* means you should get a "missing 'p'" error.
Previously, the function which was called here was typed as `any`. I think it's because it was assigned `any` outside the constructor. Regardless, the new type is correct.

comments.body: Here, webpack uses `{T=}` to indicate `T | undefined`, not possibly-missing. I thought that's what we and closure understood it to mean, too, so I need to go check.
Nope, I forgot. `?T` is the syntax for `T | null`, `T=` is the syntax for optional. Closure doesn't distinguish between `null` and `undefined` iirc.

uh oh. This looks like another case where the type reference is getting the static side of the class incorrectly.

First appeared in #34503, 15/10 15:38 PDT, new since 14/10 9:24 PDT. On both master and 3.7.
https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/34802 tracks this.

comments.body:
resolves to Position type, which I think is an addition to the DOM in 3.7

previously it resolved to the Position *value* `const Position = require('acorn').Position`, which was intentionally then given the type `any` because the webpack maintainers haven't had time to type acorn correctly.

comments.body:
OK, so this is broken because of webpack. They wrote `/** @typedef {keyof LogType} LogTypeEnum */`. `LogType` is `string`. That is `keyof string`. That is wrong. They need to write, instead, `/** @typedef {keyof typeof LogType} LogTypeEnum */`. Not really sure why this doesn't error in however they're testing their types, but it should.

cc @sokra just so yall know
